results.title: A Mile in our Shoes
results.creator_credit: Sarah Mortimer, Daniel Walker, Karl Armstrong, Steph Winward, The Junction, Middlesbrough Football Club Study Support, Riverside Studios and First Light
results.brief_description: The average age of a young carer in the UK is 12. This is a poignant and moving tribute to those many young carers tending to parents or siblings or both. They manage the domestic needs of a household as well as the physical needs of those they are caring for. They sometimes care for more than one family member with ailments ranging from autism to muscular dystrophy. With a constant lack of understanding from the rest of the world, no wonder there is little time for sleep let alone a social life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sarah Mortimer, Daniel Walker, Karl Armstrong, Steph Winward, The Junction, Middlesbrough Football Club Study Support, Riverside Studios and First Light

results.title: One Week Later
results.creator_credit: Rachel Tunnard, Peter Snelling, Mandy Rathbone, Ferndown Upper School, PVA Medialab and First Light
results.brief_description: Told through the eyes of a younger pupil, who surveys the relationships his brother has with his peer group. As revelations and misunderstandings occur, due to the misuse of the ubiquitous mobile phone, the week’s events come to a climax on a Friday afternoon.

results.title: The Box
results.creator_credit: Patrick Young, Felix Drake, Phoebe Flemming, eShed, Watershed and First Light
results.brief_description: This short drama is a tight observation of family life during the recession. Shot in a single living room, we see the ebb and flow of family life reflected in some pivotal moments through a particularly difficult time. However, the digital hearth remains a constant source of comfort.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Patrick Young, Felix Drake, Phoebe Flemming, eShed, Watershed and First Light

results.title: Hollywood Costume. Inside the wardrobe: panel discussion
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
This panel discussion explores the collaborative process between film director and costume designer, the link between costume and character and how costumes connect audiences with on-screen worlds. It also focuses on the artistic role of costuming in the filmmaking process.

Hear from leaders in costuming, film and fashion, the influential Australian film and television costumers Edie Kurzer (‘South Solitary’, ‘Look Both Ways’, ‘Matching Jack’) Cappi Ireland (‘I Frankenstein’, ‘Animal Kingdom’, ‘The Slap’) and Anna Borghesi (‘Mao’s Last Dancer’, ‘Ned Kelly’ ,’Romper Stomper’) in a discussion chaired by NIDA’s Head of Costume, Fiona Reilly.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Sam Mapplebeck, Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI

results.title: Hollywood Costume: Deborah Nadoolman Landis interview
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Professor Deborah Nadoolman Landis, an Oscar nominated Hollywood costume designer (‘Raiders of the Lost Ark’, ‘Blues Brothers’, Michael Jackson’s ‘Thriller’) is the author of ‘Hollywood Costume’ (2012), the prize-winning catalogue for the exhibition, and ‘Hollywood Sketchbook: A Century of Costume Illustration’ (2012) among many other volumes. Landis received her Ph.D. from the Royal College of Art in London and is the Founding Director of the David C. Copley Center for Costume Design at the UCLA School of Theater, Film and Television.
In this interview she talks about the origins of the Hollywood Costume industry, working as a costume designer, what a costume designer does and the relationship between the director and the costume designer.

results.title: Hollywood Costume: Interview with Jan Chapman and Janet Patterson
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
The 2009 film ‘Bright Star’ (directed by Jane Campion)tells the story of the romance between the English poet John Keats (1795 - 1821)and Fanny Brawne.
In this interview, ‘Bright Star’ producer Jan Chapman and costume designer Janet Patterson discuss the creative process behind costume design, and the design choices that went into making one of the costumes for the character Fanny Brawne (played in the film by Abbie Cornish).
The character’s crimson gown costume was on display during the ACMI Melbourne Winter Masterpieces ‘Hollywood Costume’ exhibition (2013).
Clips from ‘Bright Star’ (2009) courtesy of Hopscotch Films.

results.title: Welcome to Cape Conran
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: Have you ever wondered what it’s like to live and work in a National Park? Cape Conran Coastal Park consists of 11,700 hectares of pristine coastal wilderness. Meet Carla and Josh Puglisi who manage the park as well as Mike Irvine; the park ranger, as they talk about the importance of protecting the coastal environment, the rich indigenous history of the area as well as what it’s like living within and raising families in such a beautiful place.

results.title: Paddle Steamer Curlip
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Kim Montgomery, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Join a group of passionate volunteers as they describe the trials, tribulations and joys of building and running a paddle steamer. From the initial planning in 2002, a group of Orbost locals built the PS Curlip II as part of a community project. After 16,000 hours of voluntary labour the paddle steamer was launched and continues in 2013 to transport tourists in and around the various waterways of East Gippsland. Members of the PS Curlip Committee talk about the history, their involvement and the future of the much-loved paddle steamer.

results.title: Orbost Locals
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: Learn about the town of Orbost through a diverse range of locals as they talk about why they love their town, their community and the surrounding environment. Meet Mick Colling, the publican of the Orbost Club Hotel, who is heavily involved in fundraising within his local community and in particular for Ronald McDonald House. Lachie Macalister, a ‘true’ local and over eighty years old, has lived and farmed in Orbost all his life, growing everything from potatoes to pumpkins and working the land with pigs and cattle. Heather Terrell is many things: a passionate gardener, volunteer and member of the local historical society. Liz Mitchell, a tree changer and small business owner who decided to move to Orbost because she loved the environment and wanted to raise her family in a rural region. Finally, there’s Sam Mitchell, an 18-year-old student known around town for the extraordinary machines he builds and rides.

results.title: Lakes Entrance Fishing
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Kim Montgomery, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: A story about a fishing family and the importance of the fishing industry within the town of Lakes Entrance. Arthur Allen and his family have maintained a tradition of lake fishing in East Gippsland for five generations and hope to continue for many years to come. Despite the uncertainty of the industry, Arthur, his son Matthew and the Lakes Entrance Fishermen’s Co-op, strive to keep fishing alive in Lakes Entrance.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roberto Salvatore, Kim Montgomery, David Withers and ACMI
